segment_metadata.text_summary: This passage explores themes of suffering, divine love, and God's sovereignty in choosing Israel. It begins with the author expressing deep sorrow for his Jewish brethren, even wishing to be accursed for their sake. The text affirms God's love, which cannot be overcome by any force. It then delves into the complex relationship between Israel and God's promises, asserting that not all who are descended from Israel are truly Israel. God's election is based on His own purpose, not on works. The passage uses examples from the Old Testament (Isaac, Jacob and Esau, Moses, Pharaoh) to illustrate God's freedom and authority in choosing whom to show mercy and whom to harden. It concludes by emphasizing God's right to shape humanity as a potter shapes clay, preparing some for wrath and others for glory, including both Jews and Gentiles. The remnant of Israel will be saved.
